The pivot of moral choice has three components. These are: (1) personal reason (2) emotional backdrop (3) socio-cultural compulsion. The first and the last factors are, more or less, understood. But the middle one is mostly misunderstood. Emotions are already built-in and represent the very genetics. Collectively, the emotions are known as the subconscious. Contrary to conventional beliefs, the subconscious emotion isn’t really a mystery. It is simply “translated intellect” and “inherent/ latent memory”. Let me explain. When intellectual products i.e. ideas are sustained in mind for a critical length of time in the form of beliefs or inferences, rectified or of limited rectitude, they are subject to internal “realization” that converts the ideas into characteristic emotions and installs them corporally, that is, embodies them as respective mini-genes (dna-s). You should be able to imagine now that your whole genetics is built up in this process in course of time. To wit, emotions are pre-installed agents that influence your morality. More incomplete is your personal reason and beliefs, more awry are the emotions thereof and more moral distraction they cause. Emotions are your very own. You would be more intimate with your emotions than with your intellect. And yet awry part of your emotions are definitely not your own. Though you could be under the impression so far that your intellect is your own, you have to rethink how dear they could be to you if your personal inferences and personal reason they constitute would be riddled with inveracity (nonconformity with facts or reality)? So, you see, all the three factors which determine your moral choices aren’t really your own.

response.answer_text: Moral choices are our own. Not having it this way would imply that those who commit crimes should not be punished. Personal responsibility will go for a toss. Any criminal can just claim that it was the mysterious forces of nature that led them to do this. Now this is basically arguing from the perspective that keeping moral choices not as our own would lead to havoc in law and order. Right now the moral choice being that of the actor as a system is leading to good laws and better society. Therefore from a pure utility perspective it is justified to believe that moral choice belong to the actor. Is this argument conclusive of the truth? No. No question in philosophy really is, we have to make those assumptions that have the best consequences.
